title: For Sale/Trade:  2 VERY nice Remington Model 81 Woodsmasters 35 Rem and 300 Savage
postcontent:
I have two Remington 81s ("Woodsmaster") and I would like to sell one of them. I'm planning on keeping whichever one I don't sell, but I may let them both go for the right offer. 

The first is a 1946 35 Remington caliber in great shape. I'd give this one a grade of 90% overall. The wood is in great shape with only a couple very minor imperfections. The barrel and receiver both have very nice factory bluing, lacking only the "new gun" luster. The main reason I'd say it's 90% is the stainless steel slide and inside of the chamber have some discoloring, and it was tapped for a scope. 

The second is a beautiful 1948 model in 300 Savage. The very cool and rare thing about this gun is the checkered stock. Almost all of the 81's that had the checkered stock were the Model B, which came standard with it. This one, however, is the Model A that somebody ordered a custom factory checkering on. Very cool! This can be confirmed and view at the following site:

http://thegreatmodel8.remingtonsociety.com/?page_id=1051 

The 1948 has a receiver nearly like new, and the stock is flawless and shines like it's from the factory! The only imperfection on this gun is the barrel, which has some light surface rust that is hard to see. I'd give this gun 95-97%. 

The other cool thing about these guns is that the design was actually patented by John Browning, and is the same as his A5 shotgun! 

Price on the ad is what I'm asking for the 1946. The other is considerably more valuable. Also have a couple boxes of ammo for the 35 (valued at $40/box) and a couple rounds for the 300 Savage. If the ad is up I still have them. I will modify it if one sells and I decide to sell the other. Feel free to contact with questions, thanks.

This doesn't really fit into my collection right now, so I figure I'll see what kind of interest there is. 

This is a German-marked and produced VZ-24.  From the research I've done and information I've been able to find, this rifle was produced shortly after Germany obtained control of Czechoslovakia.  As they took control of the country, they also took control of the arsenals and weapons plants.  This rifle is a product of that.

You can see the German proof marks pictured.  From what I've found, this is a predecessor to the German G24(t) that was produced in the Czech plants.  The Germans used up the parts in stock, then switched over to the German design.   This appears to be in the first year of production, first run of 10K of the German produced rifles in Czechoslovakia being built in 1941. The subsequent runs of 10K had a suffix to the SN.

The bolt and stock do not have matching serial numbers. I obtained it in a trade with the sporter stock (included and pictured) and put it back into it's original form with a replacement stock (not SN matched, either) and metal.  Both stocks go with this rifle.
